
# MCP Handler ‚Äì Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server

The **MCP Handler** in OpenFusionAPI provides a turnkey Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for a given application environment.  
This handler exposes application endpoints (that have MCP enabled) as **tools** following the MCP standard so that AI agents can discover and invoke them as capabilities.

---

## General Overview

- **Handler Type:** MCP (Model Context Protocol server)  
- **HTTP Method:** POST (single allowed method)  
- **Route:** Fixed per application and environment (for example: `/api/<app>/mcp/server/<env>`). The route cannot be modified except by selecting the environment.  
- **Scope:** The handler auto-detects all endpoints in the same application that have the **MCP option enabled**. Each detected endpoint becomes an MCP tool.  
- **Requirement:** Each endpoint to be exposed as an MCP tool **must** have a properly defined **JSON Schema** and a detailed **description** so AI consumers can use the tool reliably.  
- **Implementation:** Internally OpenFusionAPI uses `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk` to build and serve the MCP metadata and endpoints.

> **Recommendation:** Use [modelcontextprotocol/inspector](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/inspector) to validate and test your MCP server and tools during development.

---

<details>
<summary>üß† How It Works</summary>

1. The MCP Handler is invoked via `POST` on the application-specific MCP server route.  
2. OpenFusionAPI scans the application for endpoints that have the **MCP tools** option enabled.  
3. For each enabled endpoint, OpenFusionAPI reads the endpoint metadata: path, method, description, and **JSON Schema** (input / output definitions).  
4. The MCP server composes MCP-compliant metadata (tools catalog) using `@modelcontextprotocol/sdk`.  
5. The MCP handler returns the standard MCP metadata payload to the caller (an MCP inspector or an AI model client).  
6. AI agents or inspector tools consume the MCP metadata to discover available tools and invocation schemas.

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>‚öôÔ∏è Configuration Section</summary>

This handler is largely automatic. You configure MCP behavior by enabling the **MCP tools** option on the endpoints you want to expose and ensuring each endpoint includes a complete **JSON Schema** and a descriptive documentation string in the endpoint configuration UI.

![MCP Endpoint Configuration](data:image/png;base64,)

**Key notes:**

- The MCP handler itself is invoked with a `POST` to the fixed MCP route for the application and environment.  
- Endpoint-level control (enable/disable MCP tools) determines which tools are published.  
- JSON Schema must accurately reflect the request/response shapes and field descriptions for best AI usability.

</details>

---

## Parameters Section

The MCP handler requires **no request payload** to list the tools ‚Äî a simple `POST` request to the MCP endpoint will return the MCP metadata. Authentication is handled at the endpoint level (see Authentication section).

**Configuration inputs (in the UI):**

- Enable **MCP tools** on each endpoint you want to publish.  
- Add complete **JSON Schema** to each endpoint (input and response).  
- Provide a detailed human-readable **description** for every endpoint/tool.


---

<details>
<summary>üì§ Example Request / Response</summary>

**Example Request (POST):**

```bash
curl -X POST 'https://yourserver.com/api/demo/mcp/server/dev'   -H "Authorization: Bearer <token>"   -H "Content-Type: application/json"   -d '{}'
```

> Note: The MCP server endpoint typically does not require a request body. Authentication headers apply as configured for the endpoint.

**Example Response (representative ‚Äî actual payload follows the MCP standard):**

```json
{
  "mcp_version": "1.0",
  "tools": [
    {
      "id": "get_user_by_id",
      "name": "Get user by id",
      "description": "Retrieves a user by its identifier.",
      "entry_point": "/api/demo/users/get_by_id/dev",
      "method": "POST",
      "schema": {
        "type": "object",
        "properties": {
          "id": { "type": "string", "description": "User identifier" }
        },
        "required": ["id"]
      }
    },
    {
      "id": "create_order",
      "name": "Create order",
      "description": "Create a new sales order in the system.",
      "entry_point": "/api/demo/orders/create/dev",
      "method": "POST",
      "schema": { "type": "object", "properties": { "items": { "type": "array" } } }
    }
  ]
}
```

**Important:** The real response follows the MCP specification exactly (names, fields and nesting conform to the standard). The example above is a simplified representation for documentation purposes.

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>üîê Authentication</summary>

Access control for the MCP endpoint follows the same model as other OpenFusionAPI endpoints: **Public**, **Basic Auth**, or **Token-based**.  Configure authentication at the MCP endpoint level to control which clients (or AI agents) can discover and call your tools.

**Best practice:** Use token-based authentication for production MCP servers and restrict which tools are published to only those safe for AI consumption.

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>ü™µ Cache and Logging</summary>

- **Cache:** The MCP handler can be configured with the same cache timeout (in seconds) as other handlers. Caching the MCP metadata can reduce load and accelerate discovery for repeated client requests.  
- **Logging:** All MCP requests and responses are logged via the OpenFusionAPI global logging system (timestamp, client IP, endpoint, execution time, tool count, errors).

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>üõë Errors Handling</summary>

The MCP handler returns standard HTTP status codes and MCP-compliant error payloads where applicable:

- **400 Bad Request** ‚Äî If the request is malformed.  
- **401 / 403** ‚Äî Authentication or authorization issues.  
- **404 Not Found** ‚Äî If the MCP route or application is not available.  
- **500 Internal Server Error** ‚Äî If the MCP server fails to compose metadata or internal SDK errors occur.

Additionally, if an endpoint lacks a JSON Schema or description, that endpoint will be **omitted** from the published tools list; the handler will still return metadata for the remaining valid tools. A diagnostic message may appear in the logs describing the omission.

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>üìä Capability Summary</summary>

| Feature | Supported |
|---|---:|
| HTTP Method | POST only |
| Automatic tool discovery | ‚úÖ |
| Requires JSON Schema per endpoint | ‚úÖ |
| Returns MCP metadata | ‚úÖ (via @modelcontextprotocol/sdk) |
| Endpoint-level access control | ‚úÖ |
| Tool-level filtering (MCP toggle) | ‚úÖ |
| Testable with inspector | ‚úÖ (modelcontextprotocol/inspector) |

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>üí° Recommended Use Cases</summary>

- Exposing curated application tools to LLM-based agents.  
- Rapid prototyping of AI-driven workflows that call application endpoints as tools.  
- Integration testing of tool schemas and documentation using MCP inspector.  
- Controlled production exposure for internal AI agents with token-based access.

</details>

---

<details>
<summary>üßæ Good Practices</summary>

- Provide complete **JSON Schema** for every published endpoint (request and response) including types, `required` fields and field descriptions.  
- Add detailed human-friendly **descriptions** and examples for every tool.  
- Avoid publishing endpoints that modify or delete sensitive data unless protected by strict scopes.  
- Validate schemas regularly and run the MCP inspector to ensure compatibility with MCP clients.  
- Use per-tool documentation and sample request/response examples in the endpoint configuration UI.

</details>

---

<summary>üß∞ TODO</summary>

- Validate and preview tool schemas at publish time.  
- Provide SDK examples for popular LLM frameworks and clients.
